   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:45.2/41.4/4.8, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:374/11/, ALT / AST:95/71, Alk Phos / T Bili:206/0.7, Lactic
   Acid:1.3 mmol/L, Albumin:3.4 g/dL, LDH:273 IU/L, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:5.8 mg/dL
   UCx pending
   IMAGING:
   [**2148-11-29**] ECHO:
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is moderately
   dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left
   ventricular cavity size is borderline dilated. There is severe regional
   left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior and inferolateral
   akinesis. There is moderate to severe hypokinesis of the remaining
   segments (LVEF <20%). The estimated cardiac index is depressed
   (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle.
   The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe global
   free wall hypokinesis. There is abnormal diastolic septal
   motion/position consistent with right ventricular volume overload, as
   well as a conduction abnormality or RV apical pacing. The aortic valve
   leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and
   no aortic stenosis. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation
   is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is at
   least mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, athough this may be
   underestimated given severity of TR. There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Dilated left ventricle with severe regional and global
   systolic dysfunction, c/w prior extensive inferior myocardial
   infarction and a superimposed process (or multivessel CAD). Markedly
   dilated right ventricle with severe global systolic dysfunction. Mild
   aortic regurgitation. Moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.
   Depressed cardiac index and at least mild pulmonary hypertension.
   CXR: ETT balloon hyperinflated. Low lung volumes, with possible mild
   vascular congestion. Moderate cardiomegaly.
   CT head: No acute intracranial abnormality. No intracranial hemorrhage
   or loss of [**Doctor Last Name **]-white matter differentiation.
   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: ?PEA arrest. Defibrillator interrogated and showed no VF.
   Several episodes of VT over the last several weeks.
   - re-warm today
   - sedation with fentanyl and versed, wean today
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - continue home mexiletine
   - monitor neuro status, call neuro to examine when pt is awake
   - holding coumadin for a-fib
   - cont home amio
   - head CT negative for acute intracranial abnormality
   - f/u EP recs
   -
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF. Patient appears to be overloaded on exam.
   Although JVP difficult to assess. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of
   pulm edema on CXR.
   - dobutamine 5mcg/min to improve CI
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - Lasix bolus with gtt
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - wean sedation and vent as tolerated
   - Lasix bolus, followed by gtt
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and
   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis, but likely reactive.
   Pt afebrile and no clear source of infection. CXR no infiltrate. Pt was
   started on neo and levo in the ED.
   - dobutamine, as above
   - maintain MAPS >60
   - trend fever curve and leukocytosis
   .
   # Gap Acidosis: Pt gap was 20 on admission. Lactate 2.4. Likely
   combination of lactic acidosis from hypoperfusion and uremia given Cr
   5.3.
   - sodium bicarb in D5
   - management of underlying cause as above
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Pt with Cr 5.3. No baseline for
   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP per family
   - renal recs appr, no HD at this time
   - sodium bicarb, as above
   - check PTH
   .
   #. Leukocytosis: Likely reactive in the setting of VF arrest. No clear
   source of infection.
   - management as above
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow. Bili is wnl making
   obstruction unlikely.
   - cont to trend
   .
   #. Gout: holding meds for now
   .
   FEN: NPO, novasource TF
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line, and CVL
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin (supratherapeutic INR)
   -Pain management
   -Bowel regimen
   .
   CODE: FULL for now
   .
   COMM: Wife [**Name2 (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12068**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2148-11-29**] 02:00 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2148-11-29**] 03:06 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2148-11-29**] 04:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   Medical Decision Making
   Pt remains sedated and intubated. No spontaneous movements yet but he
   remains on Fentanyl and Versed. EEG and post-arrest study drug
   continue. He is now warming as cooling has completed. Volume status is
   + 4.7L per 24 hours and CXR shows CHF. Fio2 has increased to 50% as
   well. WBC improving, creat fluctuating around 4.8. CK peak is 520 with
   MB 13. LFTs are slightly lower than yesterday. Echo shows global hypo
   with EF 20% (down from 35% from outside cardiologist). ICD
   interrogation demonstrates multiple episodes of VT treated by ATP and
   no shocks but no events to corrospond to 7pm Friday when the patient
   arrested per his family. Today we will lighten or discontinue the
   sedation and assess underlying neuro function. Continue amio and
   mexilitine per neuro for VT. Increase Dobuta to 5 mcg/kg/min to augment
   CI (1.1 by echo) as well as lasix drip.
   Above discussed extensively with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name 372**] or health
   care proxy. I have discussed this plan with Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 7045**] and [**Doctor Last Name 2351**].
   Total time spent on patient care: 40 minutes of critical care time.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease, who presented after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. He was intubated and sedated, and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and vasopressors. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a left bundle branch block (LBBB) with no old leads to compare. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a troponin level of 0.16 and a creatine kinase (CK) level of 521, indicating a recent myocardial infarction. His left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is severely depressed, with an estimated cardiac index of <2.0 L/min/m2.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.2 g/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.5 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count (Plt): 184 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 4.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 16 mmol/L
* Electrolytes: sodium (Na): 138 mmol/L, potassium (K): 4.0 mmol/L, calcium (Ca): 8.6 mg/dL, magnesium (Mg): 2.3 mg/dL, phosphorus (P): 5.8 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Echocardiogram: severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, with an LVEF of <20%
* Chest X-ray: mild pulmonary congestion, with a moderate degree of cardiomegaly

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Chronic heart failure with a depressed LVEF
* Coronary artery disease with recent myocardial infarction
* Chronic kidney disease with a creatinine level of 4.8 mg/dL
* Atrial fibrillation on warfarin
* Intensive care unit (ICU) acquired weakness

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: cardiogenic shock, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation
2. Respiratory complications: acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), respiratory failure
3. Neurological complications: seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy
4. Renal complications: acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression
5. Infectious complications: sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infection
6. Gastrointestinal complications: gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction, and pancreatitis
7. Hematological complications: bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to support the patient's blood pressure and cardiac function.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and provide anti-arrhythmic medications as needed.
3. Manage the patient's pain and discomfort with pain medications.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and provide sedation and analgesia as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and provide supportive care as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and provide electrolyte supplements as needed.
7. Consider the use of cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to revascularize the patient's coronary arteries.
8. Consider the use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or other mechanical circulatory support devices to support the patient's cardiac function.
9. Consider the use of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) to support the patient's renal function.

   IMAGING:
   [**2148-11-29**] ECHO:
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is moderately
   dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left
   ventricular cavity size is borderline dilated. There is severe regional
   left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior and inferolateral
   akinesis. There is moderate to severe hypokinesis of the remaining
   segments (LVEF <20%). The estimated cardiac index is depressed
   (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle.
   The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe global
   free wall hypokinesis. There is abnormal diastolic septal
   motion/position consistent with right ventricular volume overload, as
   well as a conduction abnormality or RV apical pacing. The aortic valve
   leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and
   no aortic stenosis. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation
   is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is at
   least mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, athough this may be
   underestimated given severity of TR. There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Dilated left ventricle with severe regional and global
   systolic dysfunction, c/w prior extensive inferior myocardial
   infarction and a superimposed process (or multivessel CAD). Markedly
   dilated right ventricle with severe global systolic dysfunction. Mild
   aortic regurgitation. Moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.
   Depressed cardiac index and at least mild pulmonary hypertension.
   CXR: ETT balloon hyperinflated. Low lung volumes, with possible mild
   vascular congestion. Moderate cardiomegaly.
   CT head: No acute intracranial abnormality. No intracranial hemorrhage
   or loss of [**Doctor Last Name **]-white matter differentiation.
   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: Pt reportly found in VF arrest with ROSC after 2 shocks
   by EMS. On ECG rhythm shows likely sinus tach with LBBB. Unclear as to
   whether patient was actually in VF arrest given no rhythm strips with
   records. The patient reportly has had episodes of VT in the past and is
   on Mexiletine. He also has a AICD that did not fire per report. The
   patient was started on lidocaine gtt and cooling was initiated.  Likely
   arrhythmia in the setting of severe cardiomyopathy (likely ischemic)
   given history. Unlikely ACS given ECG and prior cath 3 months prior.
   CE mildly elevated, but likely combination of demand and and CKD.
   - initiate cooling protocol
   - sedation with fentanyl and versed
   - EEG in AM per protocol
   - cont lidocaine gtt for now, holding home mexiletine
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - ECG in AM
   - TTE in AM
   - cont to trend enzymes
   - monitor neuro status
   - holding coumadin for a-fib
   - cont home amio
   - f/u head CT
   -
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - trend enzymes
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - will need to obtain OSH records
   - ECG
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF. Patient appears to be overloaded on exam.
   Although JVP difficult to assess. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of
   pulm edema on CXR.
   - consider swan placement and/or milrinone to improve CO
   - TTE in AM
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - will hold on diuresis given hypotension, but consider lasix if
   pressures tolerate
   - obtain outside records
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - ABG after placement of a-line
   - sedation
   - avoid hypercapnia given cooling protocol
   - will adjust vent setting pending ABG
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and
   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis, but likely reactive.
   Pt afebrile and no clear source of infection. CXR no infiltrate. Pt was
   started on neo and levo in the ED.
   - plan to d/c neo
   - will plan to wean levo off as well and initiate dobutamine if needed
   - maintain MAPS >60
   - will send UA/UCx
   - f/u final CXR read
   - trend fever curve and leukocytosis (although difficult given cooling
   protocol)
   - IVF prn
   .
   # Gap Acidosis: Pt gap was 20 on admission. Lactate 2.4. Likely
   combination of lactic acidosis from hypoperfusion and uremia given Cr
   5.3.
   - ABG
   - cont to monitor
   - hold on bicarb gtt for now
   - management of underlying cause as above
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Pt with Cr 5.3. No baseline for
   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP per family
   - trend Cr
   - urine lytes
   - monitor UOP
   - place foley
   - check phos
   - renal U/S
   - will need baseline Cr from PCP
   .
   #. Leukocytosis: Likely reactive in the setting of VF arrest. No clear
   source of infection.
   - management as above
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow. Bili is wnl making
   obstruction unlikely.
   - cont to trend
   .
   #. Gout: holding meds for now
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, will place a-line and CVL
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin
   -Pain management
   -Bowel regimen
   .
   CODE: FULL for now, but should be addressed with family in AM
   .
   COMM: Wife [**Name2 (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12068**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a VF arrest. He has a history of CHF, CAD, and CKD, and is on medications for a-fib and ICD. He was found in VF arrest with ROSC after 2 shocks by EMS, and was started on cooling protocol, lidocaine, and sedation. His ECG shows LBBB, and his troponin level is elevated. He has severe cardiomyopathy with an EF of <20%, and is likely in cardiogenic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiomyopathy and low EF make him at high risk for cardiogenic shock, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's CHF and pulmonary edema on CXR increase the risk of respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
3. Renal failure: The patient's CKD and elevated creatinine level make him at high risk for acute kidney injury, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.
4. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and lack of clear source of infection make him at risk for sepsis, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding and use of anticoagulants increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.
6. Hypotension: The patient's cardiogenic shock and use of vasodilators increase the risk of hypotension, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.
7. Arrhythmias: The patient's history of arrhythmias and use of medications that can cause arrhythmias increase the risk of arrhythmias, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of mortality.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management of his cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, and renal failure. He should be managed with a multidisciplinary team, including cardiology, pulmonology, and nephrology. His medications should be adjusted to optimize his cardiac function and prevent further complications. He should also be monitored for signs of sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and hypotension, and treated promptly if they occur.

   [**2148-11-29**] ECHO:
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is moderately
   dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left
   ventricular cavity size is borderline dilated. There is severe regional
   left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior and inferolateral
   akinesis. There is moderate to severe hypokinesis of the remaining
   segments (LVEF <20%). The estimated cardiac index is depressed
   (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle.
   The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe global
   free wall hypokinesis. There is abnormal diastolic septal
   motion/position consistent with right ventricular volume overload, as
   well as a conduction abnormality or RV apical pacing. The aortic valve
   leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and
   no aortic stenosis. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation
   is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is at
   least mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, athough this may be
   underestimated given severity of TR. There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Dilated left ventricle with severe regional and global
   systolic dysfunction, c/w prior extensive inferior myocardial
   infarction and a superimposed process (or multivessel CAD). Markedly
   dilated right ventricle with severe global systolic dysfunction. Mild
   aortic regurgitation. Moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.
   Depressed cardiac index and at least mild pulmonary hypertension.
   CXR: ETT balloon hyperinflated. Low lung volumes, with possible mild
   vascular congestion. Moderate cardiomegaly.
   CT head: No acute intracranial abnormality. No intracranial hemorrhage
   or loss of [**Doctor Last Name **]-white matter differentiation.
   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: Pt reportly found in VF arrest with ROSC after 2 shocks
   by EMS. On ECG rhythm shows likely sinus tach with LBBB. Unclear as to
   whether patient was actually in VF arrest given no rhythm strips with
   records. The patient reportly has had episodes of VT in the past and is
   on Mexiletine. He also has a AICD that did not fire per report. The
   patient was started on lidocaine gtt and cooling was initiated.  Likely
   arrhythmia in the setting of severe cardiomyopathy (likely ischemic)
   given history. Unlikely ACS given ECG and prior cath 3 months prior.
   CE mildly elevated, but likely combination of demand and and CKD.
   - initiate cooling protocol
   - sedation with fentanyl and versed
   - EEG in AM per protocol
   - cont lidocaine gtt for now, holding home mexiletine
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - ECG in AM
   - TTE in AM
   - cont to trend enzymes
   - monitor neuro status
   - holding coumadin for a-fib
   - cont home amio
   - f/u head CT
   -
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - trend enzymes
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - will need to obtain OSH records
   - ECG
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF. Patient appears to be overloaded on exam.
   Although JVP difficult to assess. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of
   pulm edema on CXR.
   - consider swan placement and/or milrinone to improve CO
   - TTE in AM
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - will hold on diuresis given hypotension, but consider lasix if
   pressures tolerate
   - obtain outside records
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - ABG after placement of a-line
   - sedation
   - avoid hypercapnia given cooling protocol
   - will adjust vent setting pending ABG
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and
   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis, but likely reactive.
   Pt afebrile and no clear source of infection. CXR no infiltrate. Pt was
   started on neo and levo in the ED.
   - plan to d/c neo
   - will plan to wean levo off as well and initiate dobutamine if needed
   - maintain MAPS >60
   - will send UA/UCx
   - f/u final CXR read
   - trend fever curve and leukocytosis (although difficult given cooling
   protocol)
   - IVF prn
   .
   # Gap Acidosis: Pt gap was 20 on admission. Lactate 2.4. Likely
   combination of lactic acidosis from hypoperfusion and uremia given Cr
   5.3.
   - ABG
   - cont to monitor
   - hold on bicarb gtt for now
   - management of underlying cause as above
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Pt with Cr 5.3. No baseline for
   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP per family
   - trend Cr
   - urine lytes
   - monitor UOP
   - place foley
   - check phos
   - renal U/S
   - will need baseline Cr from PCP
   .
   #. Leukocytosis: Likely reactive in the setting of VF arrest. No clear
   source of infection.
   - management as above
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow. Bili is wnl making
   obstruction unlikely.
   - cont to trend
   .
   #. Gout: holding meds for now
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, will place a-line and CVL
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin
   -Pain management
   -Bowel regimen
   .
   CODE: FULL for now, but should be addressed with family in AM
   .
   COMM: Wife [**Name2 (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12068**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now

   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the

   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:

   Pt remains sedated and intubated. No spontaneous movements yet but he
   remains on Fentanyl and Versed. EEG and post-arrest study drug
   continue. He is now warming as cooling has completed. Volume status is
   + 4.7L per 24 hours and CXR shows CHF. Fio2 has increased to 50% as
   well. WBC improving, creat fluctuating around 4.8. CK peak is 520 with
   MB 13. LFTs are slightly lower than yesterday. Echo shows global hypo
   with EF 20% (down from 35% from outside cardiologist). ICD
   interrogation demonstrates multiple episodes of VT treated by ATP and
   no shocks but no events to corrospond to 7pm Friday when the patient
   arrested per his family. Today we will lighten or discontinue the
   sedation and assess underlying neuro function. Continue amio and
   mexilitine per neuro for VT. Increase Dobuta to 5 mcg/kg/min to augment
   CI (1.1 by echo) as well as lasix drip.
   Above discussed extensively with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name 372**] or health
   care proxy. I have discussed this plan with Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 7045**] and [**Doctor Last Name 2351**].

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a VF arrest. He has a history of CHF, CAD, CKD, and a-fib on coumadin. The patient's current condition is severe cardiomyopathy with a low EF, likely due to ischemic cardiomyopathy. He is intubated and sedated, and is receiving cooling protocol, lidocaine, and dobutamine. His lab results show elevated CK and Troponin-T, and his ECG shows LBBB with no old to compare. The patient's cardiologist is considering medical management, including ASA and lipitor, and may need to obtain OSH records.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: Given the patient's severe cardiomyopathy and low EF, cardiogenic shock is a high-risk complication.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's intubation and sedation may lead to respiratory failure, especially if his lung volumes are low.
3. Renal failure: The patient's CKD and potential hypoperfusion may worsen his renal function, leading to acute kidney injury.
4. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and potential infection may lead to sepsis, especially if his underlying cardiomyopathy is not well-managed.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of CKD and potential hypoperfusion may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and potential hypoperfusion may lead to neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
7. Infection: The patient's intubation and sedation may increase his risk of infection, especially if his underlying cardiomyopathy is not well-managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue cooling protocol and monitor the patient's temperature closely.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac function closely and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his fluid management as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust his sedation regimen as needed.
6. Consider obtaining OSH records to better understand the patient's medical history.
7. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to further evaluate the patient's cardiomyopathy and develop a plan for management.

   - cont to trend

	* Continued episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and the need for amiodarone infusion may indicate ongoing cardiac instability.
	* The patient's history of cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25% and previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) increases the risk of cardiac complications.
	* The patient's current condition, including hypotension and leukocytosis, may be indicative of cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to the need for mechanical ventilation and the presence of pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation on the chest X-ray.
	* The patient's respiratory distress may be exacerbated by their underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the presence of pleural fluid.
3. Renal complications:
	* The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) may be caused by hypoperfusion, uremia, or sepsis, and may progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed properly.
	* The patient's current creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL and potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L may indicate ongoing kidney damage.
4. Infectious complications:
	* The patient's febrile response and leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, which needs to be identified and treated promptly.
	* The patient's pan-culture results are pending, and the presence of Staphylococcus species in the urine culture may indicate a urinary tract infection.
5. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* The patient's nausea and vomiting may be caused by their underlying condition, medications, or a gastrointestinal infection.
	* The patient's poor oral intake and need for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may increase their risk of gastrointestinal complications.
6. Neurological complications:
	* The patient's sedation and mechanical ventilation may increase their risk of neurological complications, such as pressure ulcers, respiratory failure, and sepsis.
	* The patient's EEG monitoring may indicate ongoing neurological instability or potential seizures.

Based on these potential complications, the patient's management should focus on:

1. Cardiac stabilization: Continue amiodarone infusion and monitor for ongoing VT.
2. Respiratory support: Wean sedation and ventilation as tolerated, and continue Lasix gtt to manage pulmonary edema.
3. Renal management: Monitor creatinine and potassium levels, and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Infection control: Identify and treat any underlying infections, and monitor for sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal support: Provide adequate nutrition and hydration, and monitor for gastrointestinal complications.
6. Neurological monitoring: Continue EEG monitoring and monitor for neurological complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their management plan accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

 given Amio bolus and gtt increased from 0.5

   but pt was febrile overnight. No clear source of infection.

   - cont to trend

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock due to low EF and cardiomyopathy
	* VT and VF arrest, which can lead to cardiac arrest
	* Potential for cardiac tamponade due to ICD implant
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation on CXR
	* Potential for respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
	* Risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute on chronic renal failure with Cr 5.3 and PTH 303
	* Potential for further renal dysfunction and need for dialysis
	* Risk of acidosis and electrolyte imbalances
4. Infectious Complications:
	* Fever and leukocytosis, which may indicate infection
	* Positive Staph species in UCx, which may indicate bacteremia
	* Potential for sepsis and septic shock
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Lactic acidosis due to hypoperfusion and uremia
	* Potential for further metabolic derangements, such as hyperkalemia and hypophosphatemia
6. Hemodynamic Complications:
	* Hypotension due to cardiogenic shock and potential for further drops in blood pressure
	* Potential for cardiac arrest and need for CPR
7. Neurological Complications:
	* Sedation and potential for further neurological decline
	* Risk of seizures and potential for further neurological complications

The patient requires close monitoring and management of these potential complications to prevent further deterioration and improve their clinical outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall, 76.4 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of cardiac arrest. The patient has been experiencing a fever of 102.1F, which was treated with tylenol. He has also been experiencing ventricular tachycardia (VT) and was cardioverted on his own. The patient's heart rhythm is currently sinus rhythm.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure of 109/59 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. He is intubated and sedated, and his respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac injury. His kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 17 mg/dL. His liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 47 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 76 IU/L.

The patient's imaging studies show development of pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation, which may be indicative of pneumonia.

The patient's medical history is significant for cardiac arrest, and his family wants him to receive hemodialysis (HD) if necessary. The patient's allergies include amiodarone, and he has a history of taking antibiotics.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, furosemide (Lasix), midazolam (Versed), norepinephrine, and fentanyl (Concentrate). His IV medications include furosemide (Lasix) and amiodarone.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and cardiac arrest, he is at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's imaging studies show development of pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation, which may be indicative of pneumonia.
3. Kidney injury: The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 17 mg/dL.
4. Liver injury: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 47 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 76 IU/L.
5. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is 109/59 mmHg, which is slightly elevated, and his heart rate is 84 beats per minute, which is slightly elevated.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, which may be necessary to maintain his respiratory function.

Overall, the patient is at risk for further cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory failure, which may require further medical intervention.

   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: ?PEA arrest. Defibrillator interrogated and showed no VF.
   Several episodes of VT over the last several weeks. Pt had persistent
   runs of VT overnight
 given Amio bolus and gtt increased from 0.5
   1mg/min. Dobutamine d/c
 no further VT afterwards.
   - sedation with fentanyl and versed, wean today
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - continue home mexiletine
   - f/u neuron recs
   - holding coumadin for a-fib
   - amio gtt at 1mg/min
   - head CT negative for acute intracranial abnormality
   - f/u EP recs
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF, EF<20%. Patient appears to be overloaded on
   exam. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of pulm edema on CXR. UOP
   improved yesterday on Dobutamine and Lasix gtt. Dobutamine was d/c
   overnight [**1-22**] to VT.
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - continue Lasix gtt
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - wean sedation and vent as tolerated
   - cont Lasix gtt
   - repeat CXR this AM
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and
   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis and febrile overnight.
   No clear source of infection, but patient pan-cultured. Previous CXR

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a VF arrest. He has a history of CHF, CAD, CKD, and a-fib on coumadin. He has been experiencing several episodes of VT over the past few weeks, which were treated with Amiodarone.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 102.1F, HR 84 bpm, BP 109/59 mmHg, RR 22 breaths/min, SpO2 98%
* Respiratory support: intubated and ventilated on CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode
* Cardiovascular: patient is in sinus rhythm, with a PMI located in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line
* Neurological: patient is sedated and has no purposeful movement
* Renal: patient has CKD with a creatinine level of 5.3 mg/dL
* Hepatic: patient has transaminitis with elevated liver enzymes
* Hematological: patient has leukocytosis with a WBC count of 11.3 K/uL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Cardiac: VT, cardiogenic shock, and a-fib
* Respiratory: pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation
* Renal: acute on chronic renal failure with a creatinine level of 5.3 mg/dL
* Hepatic: transaminitis
* Hematological: leukocytosis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Amiodarone infusion at 1 mg/min
* Wean sedation and vent as tolerated
* Continue Lasix gtt
* Repeat CXR this morning
* Trend fever curve and leukocytosis
* Start broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Continue Levophed for pressure support
* Maintain MAPS >60
* F/u cultures
* F/u renal recs
* F/u EP recs
* F/u pain management

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and has requested that he be started on hemodialysis if necessary. However, the patient's current condition does not warrant hemodialysis at this time.

Based on the provided medical note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a significant medical history, including coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was found to have a severe cardiac condition with a low ejection fraction (EF <20%). The patient was intubated for airway protection and was treated with dobutamine and lasix to improve cardiac output and reduce pulmonary edema.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.1F (38.9C)
* Heart rate: 84 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 11.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.8 g/dL
* Platelet count (PLT): 238 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 4.5 mg/dL
* Potassium (K): 4.1 mEq/L
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 374 ng/mL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Development of pulmonary edema and left basilar atelectasis or consolidation and possibly pleural fluid.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Cardiogenic shock
* Pulmonary edema
* Leukocytosis
* Transaminitis
* Gout
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued treatment with dobutamine and lasix to improve cardiac output and reduce pulmonary edema
* Monitoring of cardiac rhythm and management of any arrhythmias
* Treatment of leukocytosis with antibiotics
* Management of transaminitis with close monitoring of liver function tests (LFTs)
* Holding of medications for gout
* NPO status with novasource total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer
* Code status: full code

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and is aware of his treatment plan.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Persistent episodes of VT requiring APT despite increasing antiarrhythmics.
	* Cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and cardiomyopathy with low EF.
	* Potential for further cardiac decompensation due to underlying cardiomyopathy and CHF.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute on chronic renal failure with Cr 5.3.
	* Poor UOP despite aggressive lasix gtt.
	* Potential for further renal decompensation and need for dialysis.
3. Respiratory Complications:
	* Evidence of mild to moderate pulmonary edema and PNA on CXR.
	* Potential for further respiratory decompensation and need for mechanical ventilation.
4. Infection and Sepsis:
	* Leukocytosis and febrile overnight with no clear source of infection.
	* Pan-cultured and on broad-spectrum antibiotics.
	* Potential for sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Lactic acidosis from hypoperfusion and uremia.
	* Potential for further metabolic decompensation and acidosis.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* NPO pending IR line placement.
	* Potential for further gastrointestinal decompensation and need for bowel regimen.
7. Hematological Complications:
	* Transaminitis likely due to poor forward flow.
	* Potential for further hematological decompensation and need for further management.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent or mitigate these potential complications. The team should continue to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a VF arrest. He has a history of CHF, CAD, CKD, and a-fib. He is currently intubated and sedated, with a persistent episode of VT requiring antiarrhythmics. His urine output has decreased, and he has been experiencing hypotension, leukocytosis, and febrile overnight. He has a gap acidosis, transaminitis, and gout. His renal function is impaired, and he has been prescribed CVVH.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia (VT): The patient's persistent episode of VT is a significant concern, and he is at risk of developing further arrhythmias.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low EF and cardiomyopathy make him at risk of developing cardiogenic shock, which could worsen his hypotension and organ dysfunction.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's impaired renal function and decreased urine output increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and febrile overnight suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's pulmonary edema and PNA on CXR increase his risk of developing respiratory failure, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's decreased urine output and increased creatinine suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.
7. Cardiac Tamponade: The patient's cardiomyopathy and low EF increase his risk of developing cardiac tamponade, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antiarrhythmics to control VT.
2. Wean sedation and vent as tolerated.
3. Continue Lasix gtt and plan for CVVH for volume removal.
4. Cont Levophed for pressure support.
5. Trend fever curve and leukocytosis.
6. F/u cultures and cont broad-spectrum Abx.
7. Manage underlying causes of acidosis, transaminitis, and gout.
8. Hold meds for gout and continue to trend.
9. NPO pending IR line placement.
10. Continue prophylaxis for DVT and bowel regimen.

   Still with persistent episodes of VT requiring APT despite increasing
   antiarrhythmics to lidocaine and Amiodarone gtt.
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - wean down lidocaine prn
   - decrease lidocaine gtt to 0.5mg/hr
   - f/u neuro recs
   - head CT negative for acute intracranial abnormality
   - f/u EP recs, may need intervention once condition stabilize
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF, EF<20%. Patient appears to be overloaded on
   exam. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of pulm edema on CXR. UOP
   improved yesterday on Dobutamine and Lasix gtt. Dobutamine was d/c
   overnight [**1-22**] to VT.
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - continue Lasix gtt
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - wean sedation and vent as tolerated
   - cont Lasix gtt
   - repeat CXR this AM
   .

   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis and febrile overnight.

 Vanc/Zosyn

   but pt was febrile overnight. No clear source of infection.
   - management as above
   .
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow.
   - cont to trend
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of cardiomyopathy, chronic kidney disease, and recent cardiac catheterization. He was admitted to the ICU after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and is currently receiving treatment for cardiac arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: The patient's temperature is 37.3C, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, heart rate is 89 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute.
* Cardiac rhythm: The patient is in sinus rhythm, but has had episodes of slow ventricular tachycardia (VT) requiring amiodarone infusion.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 16 mmHg, and his pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) is in place.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 2,917 mL of fluids, with a net loss of 942 mL due to diuresis.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 8.1 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin is 9.7 g/dL, and creatinine is 4.6 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiomyopathy and recent VF arrest make him at high risk for recurrent cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory compromise.
3. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and fever may indicate the presence of a systemic infection, which could lead to sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease and recent catheterization may increase his risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent use of anticoagulants may increase his risk of bleeding.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's recent VF arrest and cardiac arrest may have caused neurological damage, which could lead to further complications.
7. Infection: The patient's recent catheterization and respiratory failure may increase his risk of developing a catheter-related infection or pneumonia.

To manage these potential complications, the patient will require close monitoring and treatment of his underlying conditions. This may include further cardiac medications, respiratory support, and antimicrobial therapy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with multiple comorbidities. The patient has been experiencing runs of slow ventricular tachycardia (VT) and has been treated with amiodarone and lidocaine infusions. The patient's urine output has decreased, and the healthcare team is considering initiating continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to concerns about septic physiology.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/68 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and troponin-T levels, indicating possible sepsis. The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the healthcare team is monitoring for signs of acute kidney injury.

The patient's medical history is significant for heart failure, and the patient has been treated with furosemide and other medications. The patient's skin integrity is impaired, and the healthcare team is monitoring for signs of pressure ulcers.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate levels, there is a high risk of sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
3. Heart failure: The patient's pre-existing heart failure may worsen due to the patient's decreased urine output and elevated creatinine level.
4. Pressure ulcers: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of pressure ulcers.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate due to the patient's underlying heart failure and possible sepsis.

Based on this information, I recommend that the healthcare team continues to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status closely. The patient's treatment plan should be adjusted accordingly to address the patient's underlying comorbidities and potential complications.

 given Amio bolus and gtt increased from 0.5

   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)

   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and chronic kidney disease, who presented after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His cardiac rhythm is currently sinus rhythm, and he has been receiving amiodarone to prevent further episodes of VT. He has also been treated with furosemide and lasix to manage fluid overload and pulmonary edema.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 5.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 28 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.5 mmol/L and a sodium level of 134 mmol/L. His blood glucose level is 116 mg/dL, and his lactate level is 2.4 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease, and he has been receiving hemodialysis (HD) in the past. However, his current kidney function is impaired, and he is not a candidate for HD at this time.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VF arrest and the presence of amiodarone in his medication list increase his risk of developing further cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's current kidney function is impaired, and he is at risk of developing further kidney damage or failure.
3. Pulmonary edema: The patient's history of cardiomyopathy and pulmonary edema on CXR increase his risk of developing further pulmonary edema.
4. Infection: The patient's febrile response and leukocytosis suggest that he may have an underlying infection, which could worsen his condition.
5. Hypotension: The patient's history of cardiogenic shock and low blood pressure increase his risk of developing further hypotension.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and the use of anticoagulants increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of cardiomyopathy and pulmonary edema increase his risk of developing further respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm closely and adjust his medication list as necessary to prevent further cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid management plan accordingly.
3. Monitor the patient's pulmonary edema and adjust his diuretic therapy as necessary to prevent further fluid accumulation.
4. Investigate the patient's febrile response and leukocytosis to determine the underlying cause of his infection.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his medication list as necessary to prevent further hypotension.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk and adjust his anticoagulant therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary to prevent further respiratory failure.

   #. VF Arrest: s/p artic sun protocol with no sx of seizure by EEG.

   antiarrhythmics to lidocaine and Amiodarone gtt.
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - wean down lidocaine prn
   - decrease lidocaine gtt to 0.5mg/hr
   - f/u neuro recs
   - head CT negative for acute intracranial abnormality
   - f/u EP recs, may need intervention once condition stabilize
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Pt with Cr 5.3. No baseline for
   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP despite aggressive lasix gtt. Cr trending down
   to 4.5. PTH 303.
   - f/u renal recs
   - plan to initiate CVVH
   - NPO for IR placement of temporary HD line placement today
   - start heparin gtt following line placement for history of afib
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF, EF<20%. Patient appears to be overloaded on
   exam. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of pulm edema on CXR. UOP
   improved yesterday on Dobutamine and Lasix gtt. Dobutamine was d/c
   [**1-22**] to VT.
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - continue Lasix gtt , start metalozone
   -  plan for CVVH for volume overload
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Evidence of mild
moderate pulmonary edema and PNA on

   - wean sedation and vent as tolerated
   - cont Lasix gtt , plan for CVVH for volume removal
   - cont vanc/ cefepime/ clpro for VAP
   - repeat CXR this AM
   .

   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis and febrile overnight.

 Vanc/cefepime/ cipro

   ..
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow.
   - cont to trend
   .

   .
   FEN: NPO pending IR line placement
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line, and CVL

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and atrial fibrillation. The patient presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest, which was successfully treated with cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac: The patient has a history of VF arrest and is currently being treated with antiarrhythmics, including lidocaine and amiodarone. He has a low ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25% and is at risk for cardiogenic shock.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to airway protection. He has evidence of mild to moderate pulmonary edema and pneumonia on chest X-ray.
* Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 5.3 mg/dL. He is being treated with diuretics and is scheduled for continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Neurological: The patient has a head computed tomography (CT) scan that is negative for acute intracranial abnormality. He is being monitored for seizures and has a triphasic wave pattern on electroencephalogram (EEG), which suggests metabolic encephalopathy.
* Hemodynamic: The patient has hypotension, which is likely due to cardiogenic shock. He is being treated with vasopressors, including norepinephrine.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's low EF and history of VF arrest put him at risk for cardiogenic shock, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's pulmonary edema and pneumonia can worsen his respiratory status, leading to respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure can worsen his renal function, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Neurological complications: The patient's metabolic encephalopathy and triphasic wave pattern on EEG can worsen his neurological status, leading to seizures, coma, or even death.
* Infection: The patient's history of VF arrest and cardiogenic shock can increase his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to multiorgan failure.

Based on the patient's current condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue antiarrhythmics, including lidocaine and amiodarone, to manage the patient's arrhythmias.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including his heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output.
* Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust the settings as needed to manage the patient's respiratory status.
* Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his diuretic therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his therapy as needed to manage his metabolic encephalopathy.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his therapy as needed to manage his electrolyte imbalances.
* Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and adjust his therapy as needed to manage his fever.
* Consider initiating CVVH to manage the patient's fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
* Consider initiating antibiotic therapy to manage the patient's suspected infection.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, renal failure, and neurological complications. The patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, renal, and neurological status to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and CKMB, indicating cardiac damage. The patient's liver enzymes are also elevated, suggesting potential liver damage. The patient's blood glucose levels are within the normal range.

The patient has been experiencing episodes of ventricular tachycardia (Vtach) and has required cardioversion. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows triphasic waves, suggesting metabolic encephalopathy.

The patient's neurologic examination is incomplete due to the patient's critical condition. The patient's skin and peripheral vascular examination is also incomplete.

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total fluid intake of 2,379 mL and a total fluid output of 3,855 mL. The patient's urine output is 3,180 mL, and the patient's NG tube output is 200 mL.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 550 mL. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of Vtach and the presence of triphasic waves on the ECG suggest a high risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Cardiac damage: The patient's elevated troponin-T, CK, and CKMB levels suggest cardiac damage, which could lead to further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. Here is a summary of the patient's health progress:

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C (98.1F), heart rate of 70 beats per minute, blood pressure of 91/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with triphasic waves noted on EEG, suggesting metabolic encephalopathy. A head CT scan showed no evidence of hemorrhage, edema, large masses, mass effect, or large vascular territory infarction. The patient's mental status is altered, and they are not responsive.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with a history of cardiac arrest and cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia. The patient is on pressors, including norepinephrine and lidocaine, to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, CK, and CKMB, indicating cardiac injury. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 4.1 mg/dL. The patient's liver function is also impaired, with elevated levels of ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiac arrhythmias puts them at risk for further cardiac complications, such as cardiac tamponade, cardiac rupture, or arrhythmia-related death.
2. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and triphasic waves on EEG suggest the possibility of neurological complications, such as seizures, cerebral edema, or brain herniation.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's mechanical ventilation and FiO2 of 40% put them at risk for respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, pneumothorax, or respiratory failure.
4. Renal complications: The patient's impaired renal function puts them at risk for acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or end-stage renal disease.
5. Infectious complications: The patient's impaired immune function and prolonged ICU stay put them at risk for infectious complications, such as sepsis, pneumonia, or catheter-related bloodstream infections.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: s/p artic sun protocol with no sx of seizure by EEG.
   Still with persistent episodes of VT storm despite Amiodarone and
   lidocaine gtts.  [**12-1**] had episode of sustained VT at 120 requiring
   manual defibrillation with 350J x 1.  Increased lidocaine gtt back to
   2mg/min and Amiodarone 0.5mg/min
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - continue antiarrhythmics until weaned off pressors
   - f/u neuro recs
   - cont heparin gtt for hx of atrial fibnllation
   - f/u EP recs, may need intervention once condition stabilize
   .

   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP despite aggressive lasix gtt. Cr trending down
   to 2.8 with aggressive diuresis and CVVH. PTH 303.
   - f/u renal recs
   - cont CVVH
   - cont lasix gtt and metalazone
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, and kidney disease, who presented with a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. He was resuscitated and intubated for airway protection. The patient has been experiencing episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) despite treatment with antiarrhythmics.

Current Status:

* The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 91/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%.
* He is intubated and sedated, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3.
* His neurological status is unchanged, with no purposeful movement or response to verbal or tactile stimuli.
* His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* His cardiac status is stable, with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg and a central venous pressure (CVP) of 17 mmHg.
* His renal status is stable, with a creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 21 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and VF arrest suggests a high risk of recurrent ventricular arrhythmias, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* Cardiac shock: The patient's low blood pressure and decreased cardiac output suggest a high risk of cardiac shock, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* Renal failure: The patient's history of kidney disease and current creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL suggest a high risk of renal failure, which could lead to further complications.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and current respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute suggest a high risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to further complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's history of fever and leukocytosis suggests a high risk of sepsis, which could lead to further complications.

Plan:

* Continue antiarrhythmics to manage ventricular arrhythmias.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust treatment as needed.
* Continue renal replacement therapy to manage acute kidney injury.
* Wean the patient off sedation and ventilator support as tolerated.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust treatment as needed.
* Repeat imaging studies to monitor for any signs of cardiac or pulmonary complications.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust treatment as needed.

   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: s/p artic sun protocol with no sx of seizure by EEG.
   Still with persistent episodes of VT storm despite Amiodarone and
   lidocaine gtts.  [**12-1**] had episode of sustained VT at 120 requiring
   manual defibrillation with 350J x 1.  Increased lidocaine gtt back to
   2mg/min and Amiodarone 0.5mg/min
   - continue EEG monitoring
   - continue antiarrhythmics until weaned off pressors
   - f/u neuro recs
   - cont heparin gtt for hx of atrial fibnllation
   - f/u EP recs, may need intervention once condition stabilize
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Pt with Cr 5.3. No baseline for
   comparison, but per family patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl. Poor UOP despite aggressive lasix gtt. Cr trending down
   to 2.8 with aggressive diuresis and CVVH. PTH 303.
   - f/u renal recs
   - cont CVVH
   - cont lasix gtt and metalazone
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF, EF<20%. Patient appears to be overloaded on
   exam. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of pulm edema on CXR. UOP
   improved yesterday on Dobutamine and Lasix gtt. Dobutamine was d/c
   [**1-22**] to VT.
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - continue Lasix gtt , start metalozone
   - cont CVVH for volume overload
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Evidence of mild
moderate pulmonary edema and PNA on
   CXR.
   - wean sedation and vent as tolerated
   - cont Lasix gtt , CVVH for volume removal
   - cont vanc/ cefepime/ clpro for VAP
   - repeat CXR this AM
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and
   cardiomyopathy with low EF. Pt with leukocytosis and febrile overnight.
   No clear source of infection, but patient pan-cultured. Previous CXR
   with no infiltrate. Pt on Levophed for pressure support.
   - wean Levophed, maintain MAPS >60
   - trend fever curve and leukocytosis
   - f/u cultures
   - cont broad spectrum Abx
 Vanc/cefepime/ cipro
   ..
   #. Transaminitis: Likely due to poor forward flow.
   - cont to trend
   .
   #. Gout: holding meds for now
   .
   FEN: NPO pending IR line placement
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's, a-line, and CVL
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure (EF 20-25%), coronary artery disease (CAD) with previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation on coumadin, and severe kidney disease. The patient presented after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and is currently intubated and sedated.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac: The patient has persistent episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) despite being treated with amiodarone and lidocaine. The patient's cardiac function is compromised, with a low ejection fraction (EF) and evidence of cardiogenic shock.
* Respiratory: The patient has mild to moderate pulmonary edema and atelectasis on chest X-ray, which is consistent with cardiac failure.
* Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 5.3 mg/dL. The patient's potassium level is within normal limits, but the urine output is poor despite aggressive diuresis and continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Neurological: The patient has a triphasic wave pattern on electroencephalogram (EEG), which suggests metabolic encephalopathy. The patient's head computed tomography (CT) scan is normal.
* Infectious: The patient has a heavy growth of Gram-negative rods on sputum culture and a urine culture, which is consistent with a respiratory tract infection.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of gout, but the medication is currently being held.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.3-10.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.1-9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 230-246 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 4.1-4.2 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.1-4.2 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 374 ng/mL
* CK: 521 IU/L
* ALT: 69 IU/L
* AST: 53 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 199 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 2.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.4 g/dL
* LDH: 214 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Amiodarone: 0.5 mg/min
* Lidocaine: 2 mg/min
* Lasix: 20 mg/hour
* Metalazone: 20 mg/hour
* Cefepime: 1 g every 8 hours
* Vancomycin: 1000 mg every 12 hours
* Ciprofloxacin: 400 mg every 12 hours
* ASA: 325 mg/day
* Lipitor: 20 mg/day
* Heparin: 1000 units/hour
* Calcium gluconate: 1.2 grams/hour

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac: Ventricular fibrillation, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac failure
* Respiratory: Respiratory failure, pneumonia, and atelectasis
* Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalance
* Neurological: Metabolic encephalopathy, seizures, and brain edema
* Infectious: Sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infection
* Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, and gastrointestinal obstruction

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue amiodarone and lidocaine infusions
* Wean sedation and ventilation as tolerated
* Continue diuresis and CVVH for volume overload
* Monitor for signs of cardiac failure, respiratory failure, and sepsis
* Repeat chest X-ray and laboratory tests as needed
* Consider intervention for atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure
* Continue antibiotic therapy for respiratory tract infection and urinary tract infection
* Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and pancreatitis

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. He presented after a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and is currently intubated and sedated.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 70 beats per minute, blood pressure of 91/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 10.3-10.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1-9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 230-246 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.8-4.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 21-26.4 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: potassium 4.1-4.5 mmol/L, sodium 135-140 mmol/L, chloride 101-108 mmol/L, and bicarbonate 22-24 mmol/L
* Liver function tests (LFTs): alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 53-69 IU/L, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 53-69 IU/L, and alkaline phosphatase (ALK) 199-214 IU/L
* Troponin-T: 0.16-0.24 ng/mL
* CK-MB: 11-13%

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Chronic heart failure (EF 20-25%)
* Coronary artery disease (CABG)
* Chronic kidney disease
* Atrial fibrillation
* Ventricular tachycardia (VT)
* Severe renal failure (Cr 5.3 mg/dL)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Amiodarone 0.5 mg/min for VT
* Lidocaine 2 mg/min for VT
* CVVHD for volume overload and poor urine output
* Diuresis with furosemide and metolazone
* Antimicrobial therapy with vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and cefepime for VAP
* Anti-coagulation therapy with heparin SQ and CVL
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with heparin SQ

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF)
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Sepsis

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to his underlying medical conditions and the severity of his illness. Further management and treatment will depend on his response to therapy and the progression of his illness.

   d/ced.  Still with some persistent VT, but successfully ATP with
   reduced threshold on defibrillator (HR = 113).
   - d/c EEG monitoring as no signs of seizure activity
   - cont amiodarone 100mg daily
   - cont heparin gtt for hx of atrial fibnllation
   - f/u EP recs, may need intervention once condition stabilize
   .

   for comparison, but per family, patient has severe kidney disease. Pt
   potassium wnl PTH 303. Cr trending down to 1.7 with CVVHD and good
   urine output: improving renal function vs. Creatinine clearance from
   ultrafiltration
   - d/c CVVHD for now and trend UOP
   - hold off on diuretic use
   - follow pm renal function
   - renally dose all medications
   .

   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical

   exam, CXR with minimal pulmonary edema.  Initially requiring multiple
   pressors, dobutamine was d/c
d [**1-22**] to VT and levophed is being weaned.
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - wean down pressors, consider switching to dobutamine if pt
   persistently hypotensive
   - strict I/O
   - trial of CVVHD discontinuation
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Evidence of mild
moderate pulmonary edema and PNA on CXR
   which has improved with aggressive volume removal.  On minimal
   ventilator settings and can likely be extubated if can protect airway
